For a size %s colony, this translates into a %s monthly growth rate.

The population growth rate is the percentage, per month, that a colony will progress towards a size increase. If the rate is negative, progress will be lost, but colony size will not be reduced even if progress reaches zero. The primary driver of colony growth is immigration.

Colony size is an approximate measure of the population level. A colony one size larger has many times the population.

A market chooses a single source to get its supply of a commodity. Should that source go away or become less desirable, the next best source will be used. In order of importance, a market will prefer a supplier that:

- can satisfy more of the demand
- is local to the market
- has higher accessibility from the market

Certain commodities and items are inherently more dangerous to acquire.

A commodity shortage makes an operation more dangerous, while excess stockpiles are more easily accessible and decrease the risks faced by your marines. In addition, a commodity that's locally produced - rather than imported - is less dangerous to acquire.

Casualties are also affected by other factors; hover over the "Projected marine casualties" for details.

Damage that gets through armor and shields gets applied to the hull. Taking hull damage can cause weapons and engines to become temporarily disabled, and is likely to result in casualties among the crew.
Once hull reaches zero, the ship becomes disabled, though it may be recoverable (by the winner) after the battle ends.
Armor reduces the damage taken by a percentage that depends on the relative strength of the armor compared to the amount of damage, and blocks damage from getting through to the hull.
Damage applied in a single hit is much more effective at stripping away armor than the same damage distributed over multiple hits.
Each hit reduces the amount of armor that remains in the affected area, making each successive hit more and more powerful.
The "hit strength" of beam weapons - which do not score separate hits, but deal damage continuously - is based on their damage/second.
The effective armor value can not go below %s of its original value, even if it's stripped away entirely, and damage reduction from armor can not exceed %s.

Firing most weapons (except for missiles) generates flux. Your ship has a limited flux capacity, and managing what you use it on is key to survival. You can see your current flux level on the info display in the lower left corner of the screen.
Flux gained from firing weapons is called soft flux, and can dissipate while the shields are up.
Flux gained when shields absorb damage is called hard flux and only dissipates while the shields are off - so, you can't keep shields up indefinitely while taking damage.
Fortunately, you can set any weapon group on autofire, making the weapons identify and attack targets on their own.

Welcome to the Starsector combat tutorial. This part will go over the combat basics.

Let's get started!
While the ship is overloaded, it can't fire or raise shields, dissipates flux very slowly, but can still maneuver normally.
While venting, your ship can't fire or use shields, so you generally only want to do it when it's safe.
You can also lock onto a specific enemy to ensure missiles go after it, and to see more information about it.
You can also vent flux to dissipate it at double the normal rate.

You can press %s again to clear the target.

Now, onto defenses - most ships use shields to defend against incoming damage.
Your flagship for this tutorial is a Hammerhead class destroyer. First things first - let's learn how to get it moving.

Good. Now, let's create some assignments for our ships to carry out.
Good. Now, let's order our ships to focus on the enemy destroyer.
Good. Some of the the ships in your fleet will now engage the enemy destroyer, and the rest will try to hold the objectives, with all avoiding the enemy cruiser.
It's the only target left, so they'll naturally do that anyway, but giving an "Eliminate" order will also make them more aggressive.
Let's transfer command to the Hammerhead, so you can pilot it yourself, and play out the rest of the battle.
Now that the orders are locked in, let's unpause (press
Since this is the tutorial and supply costs aren't an issue, let's deploy everything.
The bonuses these provide are modest, but they add up, especially given that if you don't hold them, the enemy will.
The enemy cruiser is tough, but relatively harmless - we'd like our ships to focus on the more dangerous enemy first.
The first thing we want to do is capture some objectives - locations especially suited for the deployment of nav buoys, sensor arrays, or comm relays.
The tutorial will resume once both objectives are captured.
To deploy ships, press the "Reinforcements" button in the upper right.

Welcome to the Starsector fleet command tutorial.

Let's get started!
You can also exit the feed by pressing
You can also manually assign a ship to perform a task. Select one of the other frigates...
You can also press ESCAPE to leave the tutorial.
You can exit the feed at any time by pressing ESCAPE.
You can keep an eye on what each ship is doing by clicking on it and selecting "Show Video Feed".
You might have noticed that you're not directly controlling a ship at the moment. This can happen if you don't deploy your flagship, or if your flagship is destroyed.

Notice that the enemy ship is now overloaded - it can't fire or use shields until it recovers.

You can avoid overload by lowering your shields before the enemy punches through them.

Now, press 1 to switch back to your Assault Chainguns and destroy the enemy ship!
Press 1 to switch to the Assault Chainguns and destroy the enemy ship.
Press 2 to switch to the Sabot missiles and keep firing until the enemy shields are down.

This next ship is using shields to defend itself.

Press 2 to switch to the 'Sabot' missile group - these do KINETIC damage, which is excellent against shields, but poor against armor - and launch a few.

Excellent! Time for some live-fire training exercises.

This next frigate will fight back - use what you've learned to defeat it. Its engines are crippled, so don't worry about it running away.

Press the right mouse button to turn your shields on and off - you might need them!

Congratulations, you've completed the Starfarer combat tutorial.

It's time to go use your newfound skills in some missions - do them in order to get the hang of it, the first few are easier.

Also, remember that you can bring up the fleet command interface with the TAB key - it'll be covered fully in another tutorial.
Here are some asteroids for company, and target practice.
Tip: holding SHIFT while pressing A or D will make your ship strafe. Your ship will auto-turn towards the mouse while strafing.
You have completed the tutorial. Press ESCAPE to go back to the main menu, or fly around a bit if you like.
Press V to vent flux from your ship.

You may have noticed that using weapons and absorbing damage with shields builds up flux.

When flux reaches maximum, you risk overload and can't fire your weapons, but if you wait, it will slowly dissipate.

There's a faster way - press V to vent all flux from the ship. You won't be able to fire or use shields while it's venting, but it's much faster than waiting for it to dissipate naturally.

Press V after dismissing this dialog to see how it works.

We're about done with damage types and combat basics.

There's another damage type - FRAGMENTATION - which is very poor vs both armor and shields, but effective vs hull (after the armor is stripped away) and vs missiles.
Move your ship away from this billboard! Use WASD to pilot.

Welcome to the Starfarer combat tutorial.

You can pause it at any time by pressing SPACE, or you can press ESCAPE to go back to the main menu.

Let's get started!

Now, let's learn to fire your weapons.

There's a Lasher-class frigate nearby - move near it and press the left mouse button to fire your guns. Go blow it up!
Press R to bring up a target overlay that gives you more information about the ship.
Press ~ to toggle the weapon firing arc display.

Very good!

The Assault Chainguns you were firing use HIGH EXPLOSIVE shells which are great against armor, but not so good against shields.
The fighters may try to run after you destroy a couple - don't let them get away!

Good work.

Nav buoys give your ships a speed and maneuverability boost, and other objectives have different benefits.

Good.

Now, let's go capture an objective. You can see a nav buoy on the directional radar along the top edge of your screen.

Move towards it and capture it!
Hold C to slow down and stop near the buoy.
As you can see, your ship is not building up flux despite the shields being under fire.
Be careful - when a ship is disabled, the explosion deals damage to all nearby ships, except for fighters.

Congratulations! You've completed the advanced combat tutorial.

It's probably a good idea to complete the fleet command tutorial next.
EMP damage does not affect shields, armor, or hull - but it can quickly disable enemy weapons and engines.

Each weapon deals damage of a particular damage type.

Kinetic damage deals 200% to shields, but only 50% to armor.
Energy damage deals 100% of its listed damage to everything.
Excellent, the enemy ship is taking hull damage now. Let's finish it off!
Excellent. Now, maneuver behind the enemy ship to disable its engines. You'll need to take out more than half to cause a total flameout.
Fire enough Sabots at the enemy ship to overload its shields.

Fragmentation damage deals only 25% to armor and shields, but usually costs little flux and has a high base DPS value, making it effective vs exposed hull, or lightly armored, unshielded targets - like missiles and fighters.

Good work.

There are two damage types we haven't looked at yet.
Great work! With the shields down and an overload in progress, the enemy ship is vulnerable. The next step is to bring down its armor.
High explosive damage deals 200% to armor, but only 50% to shields.
Let's take another look at shields. Turn on your shields and sit tight for a moment - you'll be attacked with beam weapons.
Make sure you're far enough away to avoid damage. About a ship's length should be enough.
Non-EMP weapons can also disable engines and weapons, but EMP weapons bypass armor and get the job done faster.
Ships receive an engine boost - a bonus to top speed and maneuverability - when their flux level and flux generation are at zero.
Since the enemy ship has its shields up, let's start off by firing some Sabot missiles at it - they are extremely effective at bringing down shields.
Some weapons also deal EMP damage in addition to their normal damage type.
Switch to your Assault Chainguns and punch through the armor. To break through faster, focus your fire on one spot.
That ship is now a sitting duck - it won't be able to maneuver at all until the engines are back online.
The engine boost is particularly important for larger ships, which have a much lower top speed without it.
This is because beam weapons generate soft flux when hitting shields.

This may make them seem weak - but remember that this flux still needs to be dissipated, leaving that much less flux dissipation to power weapons. Beam weapons are also very efficient and need little flux to fire.

To maintain the engine boost for a ship with autofiring weapons, you can press %s to hold fire.

Carriers will also need to press %s to pull back their fighters.
Travel through the nebula in front of your ship, noting how your ship moves faster when the shields are down.
Turning shields on - even without taking any damage - is enough to cancel the bonus.

Use the Accelerated Ammo Feeder to deal damage faster. Press %s to activate it, and fire away.

If your flux maxes out from firing, just wait a bit so it can dissipate.
We've already gone over the basics of using weapons in the previous tutorial. Now, let's take a look at picking the right weapon for the job.
Welcome to the advanced combat tutorial. Let's get started!
Your Ion Cannons deal lots of EMP damage (and little else). Switch to the Ion Cannons and disable some of the weapons on the Enforcer.
Your flagship is still the same Hammerhead, but the point defense lasers have been swapped out for Ion Cannons - more on those later.

Congratulations, you've completed the Starfarer fleet command tutorial!

<highlight>Press Escape to go back to the main menu</highlight>, and use your newfound skills in some missions.

We're almost done.

You can transfer your command to another ship during the battle. This is particularly useful if your flagship is disabled, or if you just want to start the battle in a faster ship, but then switch over to a heavier one in the later stages.

To try it, let's transfer command to the Gemini. <highlight>Click on the Gemini and select "Transfer Command" from the context menu.</highlight>

Excellent, your forces are in position! Now, let's order a strike on the unsuspecting enemy cruiser. <highlight>Click on it and select "Strike" from the context menu.</highlight>

After that's done, you can either watch the bombers carry out their strike ("Show Video Feed" from their context menu) or get into the battle yourself.

Either way, make sure the enemy cruiser is destroyed.

Smart work, the enemy cruiser is disabled!

The Dagger torpedo bombers are out of ammo, and will return to the nearest carrier (that'd be the Gemini) to refit. The blue arrows on the map indicate their destination.

After repairs, the bombers will take off fully rearmed and at full wing strength - keeping a carrier around is critical to getting the most out of your fighter craft.

But what about the interceptors? They're not much use against a cruiser, so let's just get them off the battlefield.

<highlight>Click on the interceptors and select "Retreat", under "Direct Orders".</highlight>

This costs a command point, and the order can be rescinded ("Rescind Orders" in the context menu).

Good, the bombers are on their way.

In the meantime, the interceptors have decided to attack the cruiser on their own, and the Gemini is moving up to do so as well. We don't want that - the Gemini is a freighter/carrier, and no match for a cruiser in direct combat, and neither are the interceptors.

<highlight>Left click behind your lines to make another waypoint, and select "Rally Carrier Group" to keep the Gemini there and out of trouble.</highlight>

Great work. Notice how the sensor array lifts the fog of war in a large radius - and it turns out there's an enemy cruiser lurking nearby!

Let's take a closer look.

Let's set up to give it a warm welcome. First, organize a strike force midway up the map - a couple of grid squares to the left of the Sensor Array we just captured is good.

<highlight>Left click on the desired spot to create a waypoint, and then select "Rally Strike Force" from the context menu.</highlight> The Dagger torpedo bombers, being the only strike craft in your fleet, will go there.

Now that you've got more ships on the field, let's go take another objective. <highlight>There's a Sensor Array nearby - switch back to the map by pressing %s and order its capture. Remember to unpause the game afterwards by pressing %s, as switching to the map automatically pauses it.</highlight>

Note that as Fleet Commander, you're giving the assignment to your whole fleet and not to a specific ship. Your subordinates will work out the details of which ships get which assignments.

Well done! Now you've got more fleet points to play with (and an extra couple of command points from that Comm Relay, too), and it's time to deploy the rest of your fleet.

<highlight>Go back to the map by pressing %s and click the "Reinforcements" button in the upper right corner of the screen, then deploy all of the remaining ships.</highlight>

Your flagship will enter the battlefield shortly. You can pilot it directly when the map is closed and give orders to other ships in your fleet when the map is open (remember, press %s to toggle the map).

You can also toggle the autopilot by pressing %s. It's useful when you want your flagship to fight while you're looking at the map, but do not want to pause the game.

<highlight>Now, turn off the map and fly around for a bit. Remember to press %s to unpause, if needed.</highlight>

Good! You'll need additional fleet points to deploy the rest of your fleet, and you can get them by capturing objectives.

<highlight>There's a Comm Relay nearby - these give more fleet points than other objectives. Order its capture by clicking on the objective and then selecting "Capture" from the context menu.</highlight>

Creating an assignment costs a command point, and you can't give any more orders once command points run out.

You can press %s to open and close the map, and %s to pause and unpause. To pan your view, right-click on an empty spot on the map and drag.

You can also see what your ships are doing by clicking on them and then selecting "Show Video Feed" from the context menu.

<highlight>With the map open, select your interceptor wing and click "Show Video Feed" to follow along as it captures the Comm Relay.</highlight>

Your officers respond promptly to the order, and move to the task with all alacrity. There is an edge to their call-and-response, however, as if they cannot help but acknowledge the deep sense of the gravity in this act.
"Package ready to drop, captain," your ops chief says. "On your order."
Your sensors officer detects no more unusual energy patterns from the inner rim of the accretion disc, just noise, as mindless as the background radiation of the cosmos itself.

Your sensors officer hesitates, then calls for your attention. "Captain, there's a... pattern. From the black hole. Or, rather," they pause, looking almost embarrassed. "-The energy radiated by the accretion disc.

They pull a collated sensor output map into the primary holo. "It's almost a signal. See, if we chart these fluctuations in energy output over time...

You see it now, an orderly series. Not quite a sequence of prime numbers, unless you jig the math. Statistically this is nearly impossible. Possible explanations are as unlikely: a series of planets - large moons? - with specific mass-ratio relationships, all pulled into the accretion disc at just such an angle, like an intentional message... or orderly annihilation of a constructed planetary system at a scale beyond the wildest dreams of the most bloody-minded war-planners of the Domain.

It can't be known. The pattern disappears as quickly as it arose.

A pirate fleet is approaching! First you'll spot it as a sensor contact, then as an unidentified fleet, and then - when it gets very close - you'll see its true colors.
Don't worry - the pirate ship is a shoddy rust bucket, and if you do lose, you can press %s to quick-load.

Even so, combat can be expensive, especially if there's no bounty on the enemy you fight. Deploying ships into battle reduces their combat readiness, and recovering CR consumes supplies. Battle damage can cost even more supplies to repair.
However, fighting is often necessary to survive. Wait for the pirate fleet to approach, then defeat them!

Normally, if this happens you and your remaining crew will spend some time "behind the scenes" assembling a smaller fleet of recovered ships.

The %s ability is useful for long-distance travel. Activating it will briefly stop the fleet and reduce its acceleration to a minimum, but the maximum burn level will be much higher. A sustained burn can be interrupted by other fleets activating an interdiction pulse.
You can also press and hold %s to speed up time.

Keeping your transponder on is a crippling disadvantage in hostile space, but as we're getting closer to port and we'd like to dock there, it's a good idea to turn it on.
Since turning it on and off has major consequences, it requires a double-tap to turn on or off - once to prime, and once more to confirm.

Turning on the transponder makes your fleet highly visible, and everyone seeing it will know who you are - unlike that pirate fleet you fought earlier, which had to be very close to positively identify.
While in Hegemony space, a fleet is required by law to identify itself by keeping its transponder turned on. This is a view shared by most, though not all, major factions.

Fortunately, there's a debris field nearby. Move up into it and activate your %s ability to search it for useful cargo.
If you don't acquire more supplies, your fleet will suffer through a slow but ultimately fatal decline.

Buy weapons and fighter LPCs from market, if docked at one.

Ordnance from your cargo will be preferred if that option is checked and if the alternatives are of equal quality.

Buy weapons and fighter LPCs from the black market.

Non-black-market options will be preferred if the alternatives are of equal quality.
Makes the loadout only loosely based on the goal variant.

Prioritizes installing the "Blast Doors" hullmod, which increases hull integrity and greatly reduces crew losses suffered due to hull damage.

"Blast Doors" may still be added if this option isn't checked, provided there are enough ordnance points.

Prioritizes installing the "Reinforced Bulkheads" hullmod, which increases hull integrity and makes a ship virtually certain to be recoverable if lost in battle.

"Reinforced Bulkheads" may still be added if this option isn't checked, provided there are enough ordnance points.

Remove everything possible prior to autofitting; generally results in a better fit.

However, refitting outside of port reduces a ship's combat readiness, and this option tends to lead to more changes and more readiness lost.

Spend any unused ordnance points on flux vents, capacitors, and essential hullmods.

Will not make any changes to weapon loadout, will not affect ship modules (if any), and will not spend any credits.
Use weapons and fighter LPCs from your fleet's cargo holds.
Use weapons and fighter LPCs from your local storage facilities.

Use weapons better than the ones specified in the goal variant, if there are ordnance points left to mount them.

Will add flux vents and capacitors up to the number specified in the goal variant first, then upgrade weapons, and then add more vents and some common hullmods.

Leaving some unspent ordnance points in a goal variant can help take advantage of this option.
